cluster_relations.rel_desc: Methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine are both used in amine treating to remove H2S and CO2 from hydrocarbon streams, indicating they serve similar functional roles and can be alternatives to each other.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ApplicationContext: amine treating of hydrocarbon streams for H2S and CO2 removal

remarks: Relation created to capture that these two amine treating chemicals share the same described use; semantics are approximated as an alternative/substitute relation since no explicit comparison wording is given.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is one of the four categories of stainless steels listed.
remarks: Although text just says 'duplex', entity is resolved as duplex stainless steel; relation captures the category membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is a subtype/category within the broader class of stainless steels.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two materials or chemicals can serve the same functional role in a given application and may be substituted for one another.
args.justification: The relation connects two amine treating chemicals that serve the same role in removing H2S and CO2, implying they are interchangeable in function; a symmetric predicate expressing functional substitution is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject material class has the object as a more specific subtype or category within it.
args.justification: The subject is the broader class (Stainless Steel) and the object is a specific category (duplex stainless steel); this is the superclass-to-subclass direction, best captured as 'has_subtype'.
args.remark: Inverse of 'is_subtype_of'; kept explicitly to allow both hierarchy directions in the KG.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype or category within the broader class represented by the object.
args.justification: Duplex stainless steel is explicitly described as a category within the broader class of stainless steels, matching a subtype-to-supertype taxonomic relation.

Both relations describe hierarchical category membership between a specific stainless steel type and the general stainless steel class; they are instances of the same taxonomic hierarchy family (supertype–subtype).
The link expresses that two chemicals fulfill the same industrial function and can act as substitutes; this is more specific than generic similarity and fits a substitution-oriented relation class.
Subtype/supertype relations are about defining what something is in a classification system, i.e., its taxonomic identity, not composition, causality, or usage.

The alternative relationship is grounded in the shared industrial use (amine treating of hydrocarbon streams), reflecting how the chemicals are used rather than their intrinsic identity or composition.
